description: Number of non-unitary prime divisors of n.
comments: Number of prime squares dividing n. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, May 18 2002a(A005117(n)) = 0; a(A013929(n)) > 0; a(A190641(n)) = 1. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Dec 29 2012
links: Reinhard Zumkeller, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: A prime factor of n is unitary iff its exponent is 1 in the prime factorization of n. (Of course for any prime p, GCD(p, n/p) is either 1 or p. For a unitary prime factor it must be 1.)Additive with a(p^e) = 0 if e = 1, 1 otherwise.
maple: a:= n -> nops(select(t -> (t[2]>1), ifactors(n)[2]));seq(a(n),n=1..100); # _Robert Israel_, Jun 03 2014
mathematica: a[n_] := Count[FactorInteger[n], {_, k_ /; k > 1}]; Table[a[n], {n, 105}]  (* _Jean-FranÃ§ois Alcover_, Mar 23 2011 *)
prog: (Haskell)a056170 = length . filter (> 1) . a124010_row-- _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Dec 29 2012(PARI) a(n)=my(f=factor(n)[,2]); sum(i=1,#f,f[i]>1) \\ _Charles R Greathouse IV_, May 18 2015
author: _Labos Elemer_, Jul 27 2000
extensions: Minor edits by _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Mar 23 2011
